top_comment.author: OATest

comments.text:
+OATest If you ever watch a piece of glass break in slow motion, you would 
notice that the glass begins to flex in the direction that it was hit. 
 Glass, like anything else, getting bent has a side in tension and a side 
in compression.  Glass does not have much tensile strength so it cracks on 
the tension side. Tempered glass has an outer layer in residual compressive 
stress. When the glass flexes, the residual compressive stress is still 
higher than the tensile stress due to bending.  This keeps the glass from 
breaking.  To break tempered glass, you have to hit it hard enough to 
overcome the residual compressive stress.  

If you hit a glass ball, it would "squish" like a rubber ball, and start to 
flatten out.  Not as much of course, glass is much stiffer.  At the point 
of maximum tension, where the ball bulges out the most, the glass will 
crack.  A PRD is tough because the intense residual compressive stress.  If 
you used a sledge hammer or a 20 ton press, you could shatter a PRD, by 
squishing it hard enough that the outer tensile stress overcomes the 
residual compressive stress.  

The residual compressive stress would be a function of a number of things: 
the size of the ball, the rate of cooling, the starting temperature of the 
molten glass, the coefficient of thermal expansion of the glass, probably a 
few more variables.  But in a nut shell, the hotter the ball is when it 
solidifies, and the faster is cools, the larger the outer surface is that 
is being compressed, the more residual stress is being generated.  

The force to break the ball would then be a stress/strain relationship 
governed by the poisson's ratio.  That is a property of all materials 
relating to how much if you deform a material in one direction, how much it 
deforms in the other directions.

At this point the theoretical calculations are getting mind boggling.  But 
they could be determined experimentally.  Residual stress measurements are 
very common in materials science.  So, make a drop, measure the residual 
stress, compress the ball with 3 times the measured force.
comments.author: Jacob Fuerst

comments.text:
That was a great answer, thank you so much. I learned a few things and have 
some new words to research. I have a couple follow up questions if you dont 
mind:

Is there a calculable amount of force required to break a PRD? Not from the 
tail, but if for example we had a spherical PRD, how hard would you have to 
hit it for it to overcome the toughness of the glass?

Has a spherical PRD ever been made? It seems like the logical progression 
but i cant find anything on it.

Thanks again
comments.author: OATest

comments.text:
In theory, the total stored energy is ZERO.  In a PRD, there is a balance 
between in the forces between the exterior in residual compression and the 
interior in residual tension. Lots of force, going in opposite directions, 
cancels out.  Force is a vector.  For a PRD to exist, the force exerted by 
the residual stress of the exterior can not exceed the internal tensile 
force (tensile strength x cross sectional area of the residual tensile 
region).  When a PRD breaks (or you shatter a tempered glass window, which 
operates under the same principles),  the residual compressive region is no 
longer contiguous, and the balance gets upset.  The tensile stress is now 
higher than the compressive and the drop "explodes". 

It doesn't really explode, its more like a balloon popping.  The stretched 
glass, contracts quickly in all directions.  The glass goes flying.  The 
glass ends up in very small pieces because it is the lowest energy state.  
Big pieces of glass would still hold a lot of residual energy.  The higher 
the residual stress, the smaller the pieces. 

Heat would not be generated.  Heat due to rapid failure is associated with 
atomic slip and a process called adiabatic shear.  It's not something that 
happens in glass since glass does not undergo atomic slip. 

you could make a ball of glass with the same forces in play as a PRD.  You 
might be able to do it by getting the glass very hot (so very low 
viscosity) and dropping it from a very high spot so it would form a sphere 
in free fall.  This is how lead birdshot was made back in the day, with 
what is called a shot tower.  Once it formed, it would be very, very 
difficult to shatter.  You would have to scratch or cut the glass through 
the thickness of the residual  compressive layer to get it to shatter.  
That is why the tail is the weak spot on a PRD, the layers are very thin.

comments.text:
+Andrew Gouldstone Good point. Many pure metallic structures are made from 
fairly chaotic arrangements of metal atoms, there's nothing to align, as 
the atoms simply pack in like ball bearings, unless they are crystal 
forming, in which case you get a chaotic collection of crystal shapes 
growing into each other, a little like watching frost grow.

To get a similarly structured effect as the Prince Rupert's Drop, caused 
by the pressure-forced arrangement of covalent molecules instead of 
individual atoms, you'd need a more interesting and complex compound to 
start with, having molecules that can be made to align in a similar way, 
without "flipping" into crystalline arrangements and spoiling the 
compression effect with flaws.
comments.author: Nic Guthrie

comments.text:
+krishan bansal You are correct, Krishan....the thing about glass it is 
made up of silicon and oxygen atoms...the shape of the oxygen around the 
silicon is fixed (four O around one Si in a tetrahedron)...but the Si-O-Si 
bond can rotate.  So in essence, "glass" (window-type glass) is a bunch of 
nanoscopic pyramids.  If you were to take those from a hot (soft) state and 
cool them slowly, the pyramids would arrange in a regular, and tight 
pattern.  If you were to take those and cool them quickly, the pyramids 
would just freeze where they were, and not re-arrange, forming a more open 
pattern.   Metals (most metals) don't really have this cooling-rate 
effect...you can cool em fast or slow and they will end up in the same 
arrangement.  

Now, you MAY be able to do this with an amorphous metal, but I don't think 
the differences in final volume (due to different cooling rates) are as 
long...also...amorphous metals have a much higher thermal conductivity 
(again, I think) so you wouldn't get such a high difference in cooling rate 
from outside to inside...hope this ramble helps...
comments.author: Andrew Gouldstone

comments.text:
+Anthony Gray Probably not, glass is such an amorphous solid, so you can 
make the molecules arrange like this, but most metals have pretty 
predictable structures. Again, I'm not 100 percent sure.

comments.text:
Amazing to watch. This is basically how safety glass is made. Apparently, 
if you look at a car windshield through a polariser, you can see circular 
rings where the fans blew cooled air at its surface to cool it faster than 
the interior.

It's precisely analogous to pre-stressing concrete by compressing it with 
internal tensioned steel rods; it gives the concrete the ability to 
withstand higher tension without cracking.  Trees also grow pre-stressed 
like this, which allows them to withstand stronger winds without being 
toppled.

comments.text:
I used to do a lot of glassblowing.  The principle is that glass has 
incredible tensile strength, so if you can put it in a state where it's in 
tension it behaves very, very well.  (Glass fails in compression quite 
easily, and by putting it under lots of tension, compression only reduces 
tension, rather than actually compressing the glass.)  So a drop of glass 
into water cools the outside rapidly while the inside's still hot, and then 
the inside cools later, and because the glass contracts as it cools, you 
end up with an enormous amount of tension distributed across and through 
the glass.
Windshields on cars are made the same way -- any tempered glass is.  If you 
do manage to crack a piece of tempered glass, it'll shatter completely, and 
if you listen after it breaks you can hear it still crackling away as 
smaller and smaller cracks run through it.  But to get to that point takes 
a much larger force than you'd expect, which is why you can put a prince 
rupert drop on an anvil and hit it with a steel hammer and put dents in 
both of them without injuring the glass.

Interesting side-issue: stressed glass polarizes light.  If you take two 
polarized sunglasses -- you're wearing one, and holding the other one in 
front of it -- you can *see* stress in glass.  Unstressed glass will be 
clear, but stressed glass will have colors and opacity.  This is usually 
visible on things like vases that have had arms attached.  Glassblowers 
anneal glass after working it -- cool it down slowly, to help reduce 
residual stress, but it doesn't always work.
comments.author: John Bump

+John Bump That's cool. Do you work in a glassware studio or something?  I

comments.text:
+Joshua Wonser any bullet is a bullet (that is - an object that is used for 
being shoot from the barrel of a gun) because it has certain properties 
such as - compactness (more weight per less volume). The only thing that 
bullet uses to do damage is speed and mass. Mass in this case only affects 
kinetic energy linearly, whereas speed affects it quadratically.   

What I was trying to tell you is that other object can mimic a bullet by 
obtaining the same kinetic energy.

If you hit a round object with a hammer - it will still be the same point 
of impact as it could have been with a bullet. Apart from this - the rest 
is just - kinetic energy which is the same in nature for all objects, 
except of its particular value associated with a certain object.

comments.text:
+Happy Aye! I agree with you on the definition of bullet, and how bullet is 
an element of the class "fast moving object". However, one could argue a 
human-swung hammer is also part of the class "fast-moving object".
+Anton Zuykov 's comment led OP to reword his statement to replace "bullet" 
with "fast moving object" meaning he had equated the two classes. In doing 
so the OP inadvertently changed the sentiment behind his statement making 
it overly broad.

For example, if a market tester said:
"I need a boy to test G.I. Joe toys"
then changed it to:
"I need a human to test G.I. Joe toys"
The market tester could now get the wrong demographic to test the toy.
By telling the tester a boy is nothing other than a human has the tester 
make his language overly broad and lose the sentiment he meant to convey.

All of this feels overly in depth and pedantic for a YouTube comment. Yet I 
persist, because when I see +embrezar make a correct statement that is 
ignored because it was rude I feel the need to explain.
+embrezar stop being a dick and you might positively impact the world.

Your definition for bullet is too broad, it states any fast moving object

comments.text:
Several people on the internet love to take statements and apply them in 
unintended ways to make the statement untrue.

comments.author: Doken Boken

comments.text:
+embrezar a bullet is just a small object made of heavy stuff (lead is one 
of the simple materials) that can be accelerated to a certain speed.

What I was trying to say is - in physics there is no property that is 
called - "being a bullet". Nature cares about other things... 

If you are talking about kinetic energy - that can be replicated by another 
object with the same kinetic energy. If you are talking about impulse - 
that can be replicated too.

What were you so excited about?

"That's not true at all"
What not true? that a bullet is just a fast moving object to penetrate 
skin/flash?
The whole point of why bullet can penetrate stuff and do its job is that it 
flies fast enough to compensate for the lack of mass. That is impulse and 
kinetic energy that it delivers.
What isn't true about that?
comments.author: Anton Zuykov

comments.text:
+Anton Zuykov That's not true at all. First off, what is "fast?" A 
meteorite entering the atmosphere is traveling very quickly, but it's not a 
bullet. A human falling at terminal velocity is traveling very quickly, but 
it's not a bullet. I have to hope that you were trolling and that you don't 
legitimately believe the statement you made.
comments.author: embrezar

comments.text:
+Happy Aye! It is not stronger than steel just because you can't break it 
with a steel hammer.  You can't break a steel hammer with a rupert drop 
either.  The problem is that a human swinging a hammer doesn't not produce 
enough kinetic energy to overcome the molecular bonds of a rupert drop. 
 This, however, relates to material impact resistance, not material 
strength.
The only mechanical material property that the rupert drop outperforms 
steel in is surface hardness, meaning it is more scratch resistant.

When they are geting the glass just right to make bottles they let it run 
still molten unobstructed into a steeply angled metal trough which has 
water constantly streaming down it. The glass falls into a dumpster in very 
short strands but sometimes up to 5 or 6 foot long very crooked strands 
about 3/16" in diameter. They do this for days continuesly. The dumpsters 
are dumped in special recycle yard. The pile is sometimes as big as a house 
with thousands of long strands poking out of it. If you try to pull out one 
of the strands and it is held into the pile to well it breaks just as 
pictured in the video. It seems to turn to dust intantly. It does it so 
violently it will sting your hands even through tough leather gloves. I 
have one strand that I managed to get home without breaking. I will show it 
to you some time.

top_comment.text:
This is a great video -- not just because you get to see glass explode at 130,000fps, but because he gives a really clear explanation of just why a Prince Rupert's Drop can survive a hammer-blow on its big end, but the smallest clip at its narrow end will make the entire thing blow itself into dust.

(Technically speaking, it's a catastrophic mechanical failure wave, but not an explosion: the wave of destruction moves at about Mach 0.75 through the glass, whereas by definition true explosions are supersonic. That's not just a technicality: supersonic motion creates shock waves, which are what does most of the damage in an explosion. That said, I would still recommend being careful, and wearing eye protection, around Prince Rupert's Drops.)

+rammerstheman We're not confused at all.

Your explanation about the speed of light is quite long, but amusing. I get 
the idea, however I've done some more reading on the subject and must 
reserve judgement as it gets into quantum mechanics. I can't be bothered 
with more than a passing curiosity.
Oh, and C is defined as "the speed of light in a vacuum" and is 299,792,458 
m s–1. In water light's speed is around 225,000,000 m s–1. In glass light's

comments.author: Doken Boken

comments.text:
+Harry Balzak +Doken Boken  I think you're getting a little confused. C is 
the speed of light, and not the speed of sound. The speed of sound is much 
less than the speed of light in any case, this is why you see the flash of 
thunder before the clap. The speed of light is constant, and you're also 
correct that light takes more time to travel through different mediums, 
however the reasons behind this are extemely complex and mathematical, and 
in reality aren't the same as taking a longer route. It's late and so it's 
the perfect time to have a go at explaining this. In reality, the beam 
light is still traveling at C, however the light clusters together as a 
thing called a wave packet, and this wave packet moves slower than the 
light does. It's the wave packet that you observe as your light traveling 
through the material. Imagine a line of people running forward at C, the 
guy at the front is carrying a bottle of light with a parachute attached, 
as he is running forward the wind pulls the bottle back, but  he is not 
able to slow down, so he has to pass the bottle back. If you were to 
measure the speed of the guy, it's C, but the light bottle is moving 
slower. Different mediums ie glass, water, air, have a stronger wind 
blowing on the bottle, so the light bottle will move at different speeds, 
but only ever slower than the guys/ under C. The guys are the light, and 
bottle is the wave packet. What's a bit odd is in reality, once the guy has 
passed the bottle back, he'll dissapear, so err maybe it's a bottle of 
life, I dunno. But If you even vaguely understood that then you've done 
seriously well, cuz I'm not quite sure if I do either!

comments.text:
Generally, the easiest way of understanding it is that the speed of sound 
varies, and the greater an objects density the faster sound will travel 
through it. So the speed of sound in air is what people generally refer to, 
but it's MUCH greater in glass or steel. People have done experiments to 
show this by sending sound through air for a distance, and several other 
mediums for a vastly greater distance, and them all reaching the end at the 
same time. However, you wouldn't be able to understand any language because 
our ears are adapted specifically to sound in air, but the sound still 
travels much more efficiently because objects of a greater density have 
their particles more closely placed together and make it easier for the 
sound to transfer its energy between them.
comments.author: MegaBlazewing

comments.text:
The speed of sound in glass is ~4000 m/s, which would be the upper limit 
for the rate it would break at. In this case the actual velocity its about 
1/2 that.

captions.text: Hey it's me Destin. Welcome back to Smarter Every Day. Today we're gonna do awesome science with
Orbix Hot Glass here at Lookout Mountain Alabama. Goggle up.
Science is about to happen. We're gonna use a high speed camera and learn about Prince Rupert's Drop.
[whispers] It's never been done on the internet. You're gonna learn something.
Let's go.
OK we are here inside the shop with
Cal. Cal owns the place. Can you show me how to make a Prince Rupert's Drop?
(Cal) Sure. I'm gonna gather some glass, drop it in a bucket of
cold water.
[sizzling sound]
(Destin) So after it cools down, this is what you're left with.
It kinda looks like a tadpole, but it has some really interesting mechanical properties.
We can actually hit this thing with a hammer and it won't break.

OK I'm ready. [bang]
Didn't go.
OK I think Cal is kind of a pansy so I.. You think you can break it? [laugh]
So we're gonna try again only this time I'm gonna make him hit it really hard
and I'm gonna record it with high speed. Does that work? Think you can break it? Alright. Let's do it.

The challenge is on.
(Cal) Just hit it?
- Yep.

[bang] [shattering] [laughs]
So do you think you actually broke it? I don't think

you did. You think you broke it?
- I know I broke it. [laugh]
- Let's look at the high speed.
[music]
OK so the drop broke, but technically it wasn't the
hammer that broke it. If you look close in the high speed you can see that it's the wiggling of the
tail that makes it go. This is the mystery of the
Prince Rupert's Drop. You can try
as hard as you can to break the bulb, but you can't.
But, if you even nick the tail, the entire thing will explode. Not shatter,
but actually explode. Let's go outside and I'll show you more.
OK we're gonna just run an obscene frame rate here. We have this
Phantom V1610. So, glass breaking occurs
so fast that you have to have like hundreds of thousands of frames per second, so we're gonna
have a lower resolution and we have to have a lot of light as well. We're also gonna use this Miro over
here to run about 3000 frames per second so we can get a wide shot to see the whole event.

as well.
3..2..1.. go.
[shatter]
[Awesome Music by Gordon McGladdery}
OK now we understand what a Prince Rupert Drop does, but at this point
we don't quite understand why it does it. Let's take a closer look.
OK this is called a polariscope and basically what it is is it's a filtered piece of
glass that's polarized. I have another filter here. You can see if I turn it,
then I can block out the light. Now if I put this on the camera
that you're looking through here, and then I put the Prince Rupert's Drop in between
the two pieces of glass, you should be able to see the internal stresses built up
inside the Prince Rupert's Drop. So to understand how these stresses got here, let's
use the color grey to represent nice and strong solid glass. We use red
to represent molten glass and because of the thermal expansion coefficient it's safe to assume that the
higher the temperature the larger this glass wants to be. Blue represents glass that's cooling
off, or transitioning between the two states. Because of that same thermal expansion coefficient
this glass is shrinking and basically pulling in on itself. Think of a
Prince Rupert's Drop as a bunch of little infantessimal pieces of glass with each piece trying to interact
with the pieces around it. When the molten glass is first dripped into the water, the
outside layer touches the water and immediately solidifies. This locks in that
outside shape of the drop. The inside of the drop however is still a hot expanded
liquid. As heat's transferred to the water that glass on the inside slowly begins to
cool down, and pulls in against that outside layer. The problem is that
because it's already locked in as a round solid, it only compresses tighter against
itself. This actually makes it stronger. Kind of like how an arch compresses and gets stronger when
you put your weight on it only this is in all directions. And because the cooling glass can't
move that outside layer it begins to pull against itself, causing it to be
in extremely high tension. It then hardens in this state of tension and there you have it, a
Prince Rupert's Drop. The outside is in extremely high compressive stress and the inside is in
extremely high tensile stress. If one link in this tension chain is ever cut, it
breaks on down the line, feeding off of its own stored up energy just like a chemical
explosive does. The difference here is that instead of releasing chemical potential energy
mechanical strain energy is released. This wave of energy is what we call a
failure front. You can directly measure the velocity of that failure front as long as
you have a camera fast enough. Let's give it a shot at 130,000 frames

per second.
3..2..1..go.
Got it?
[music]
So a big thanks to Cal from Orbix Hot Glass. If you found this
interesting and you want to support him by buying stuff go click on the link, wherever I
put it, and go check out his web site. Click the cat to subscribe.
With the helmet. [laugh] It's a sad looking cat.

You've never caught the cat on fire, ever?
- Never.
- Not even once?

- Never.
- These things are named for a guy named Prince Rupert, imagine that,

who lived in Bavaria back in the 1600s.
Here, here.
[shins banging on concrete laughter through pain]
He brought these over as a gift to King Charles II in England who gave them to his

Royal Society to try to figure out.
Yep ready. [clang]
Holy smokes!

- Aah the tension's killing me. [shatter]
-(Destin in background) NO DON'T BLOW UP!

- You know it blow.. blowed up?
- Yep, it blowed up.
- It BLOWED UP Y'ALL! [laugh]
